docker.Rmd

Containerizing MIRA with Docker

There are two versions of docker images for MIRA:

  • Development version for continuous integration of the application
  • Production version for deployment of the application

Software requirements

  • Docker version >= 20.10
  • Git version >= 2.21

Container dependencies

  • IRMA (stored in AWS’s ECR)
  • Dais-Ribosome (stored in AWS’s ECR)
  • spyne (stored in Quay.io’s respitory, also see our Github repo for more details about the usage of the application)

Setting up containers

  1. Pull down IRMA, Dais-Ribosome, and spyne docker images

IRMA version 1.0.2p3:

docker pull public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/irma:1.0.2p3

Dias-Ribosome version 1.2.1:

docker pull public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/dais-ribosome:1.2.1

spyne version 1.1.0:

docker pull quay.io/nbx0_cdc/spyne:v1.1.0
  1. Run IRMA, Dais-Ribosome, and spyne containers

IRMA:

docker run -v /path/to/data:/data --name irma -t -d public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/irma:1.0.2p3

Dais-Ribosome:

docker run -v /path/to/data:/data --name dais-ribosome -t -d public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/dais-ribosome:1.2.1

spyne:

docker run -v /path/to/data:/data --name spyne -t -d quay.io/nbx0_cdc/spyne:v1.1.0

-v: mount host data directory to /data directory inside the container
-t: allocate a pseudo-tty
-d: run the container in detached mode

Important Note: make sure /path/to/data are the same for all containers. This directory is mounted to /data directory inside the container.

Build development version of MIRA

This version allows you to mount the code base that is needed to develop the MIRA dashboard. Any updates or changes to the code will automatically reflects the changes inside the Docker container. This allows continuous integration (CI) of the application.

(1) Clone this respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/MIRA.git

(2) CD to MIRA folder where Dockerfile file is stored and build the docker image.

NOTE: Dockerfile contains a list of instructions and steps of how to build and deploy the MIRA dashboard.

  • Build the docker image using a build-arg flag and setting BUILD_STAGE=dev for development stage
docker build -t MIRA-dev:v1.0.0 --build-arg BUILD_STAGE=dev .

or

  • Build the docker image with a specific dockerfile for the development stage (e.g. Dockerfile.dev)
docker build -t MIRA-dev:v1.0.0 -f Dockerfile.dev .

-t: add a tag to an image such as the version of the application, e.g. MIRA-dev:v1.0.0 or MIRA-dev:latest
--file, -f: name of the Dockerfile
--build-arg: set the build stage for the docker image using the BUILD_STAGE argument. Options are dev or prod. Default is prod.

NOTE: The image took approximately < 10 mins to build

(3) After the build is completed, you can check if the image is built successfully 

docker images

REPOSITORY        TAG        IMAGE ID        CREATED        SIZE
MIRA-dev          v1.0.0     2c22887402d3    2 hours ago    1.63GB

(4) To run the MIRA-dev container 

docker run -v /path/to/data:/data -v /path/to/MIRA:/MIRA -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock -d -p 8080:8050 --name MIRA-dev MIRA-dev:v1.0.0

NOTE:

  • Change /path/to/data to your local directory where it contains all data files needed to pass to the MIRA dashboard. This directory is mounted to /data directory inside the container. Make sure /path/to/data are the same as other previous containers.
  • Change /path/to/MIRA to your local MIRA directory. This directory must contain all of the code base needed to build the MIRA dashboard.
  • /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock is used to connect the host’s docker.socket to container’s docker.socket where you can run a container inside of another container.

-d: run the container in detached mode
-v: mount code base and data files from host directory to container directory [host_div]:[container_dir]. By exposing the host directory to docker container, docker will be able to access data files within that mounted directory and use it to fire up the MIRA dashboard.
-p: map the host port to the container port and then all the requests that are made to the host port will be redirected to the Docker container [host_port]:[container_port]
--name: give an identity to the container

For more information about the Docker syntax, see Docker run reference

(5) To check if the container is built sucessfully 

docker container ps


CONTAINER ID   IMAGE               COMMAND                    CREATED        STATUS        PORTS                    NAMES
b37b6b19c4e8   MIRA-dev:v1.0.0     "bash dashboard-kickoff"   5 hours ago    Up 5 hours    0.0.0.0:8080->8050/tcp   MIRA-dev

NOTE: Here the MIRA-dev container is published on port 8080 on the host machine, and 8050 is the port of where the MIRA is published inside the container. All the requests that are made to the host port will be redirected to the Docker container.

(6) Access the MIRA dashboard on the host network

You can visit the local host using your preferred web browser, type in http://localhost:8080, and check if the dashboard is indeed hosted there.

Build production version of MIRA

This version ONLY allows you to mount the data files that are needed to populate the MIRA dashboard. In other words, you do not have access to the code base of MIRA but is using its latest containerized version of the code.

(1) Clone this respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/MIRA.git

(2) CD to MIRA folder where Dockerfile file is stored and build the docker image.

  • Since the image is built with the prod stage by DEFAULT, you can omit the build-arg flag during the build.
docker build -t MIRA-prod:v1.0.0 .

or

  • Build the docker image with a specific dockerfile for production stage (e.g. Dockerfile.prod)
docker build -t MIRA-prod:v1.0.0 -f Dockerfile.prod .

-t: add a tag to an image such as the version of the application, e.g. MIRA-prod:v1.0.0 or MIRA-prod:latest
--file, -f: name of the Dockerfile

NOTE: The image took approximately < 10 mins to build

(3) After the build is completed, you can check if the image is built successfully. 

docker images

REPOSITORY        TAG        IMAGE ID        CREATED        SIZE
MIRA-prod         v1.0.0     6dab1b639b9a    2 hours ago    1.63GB

(4) To run the MIRA-prod container 

docker run -v /path/to/data:/data -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock -d -p 8050:8050 --name MIRA-prod MIRA-prod:v1.0.0

NOTE:

  • Change /path/to/data to your local directory where it contains all data files needed to feed into the MIRA dashboard. This directory is mounted to ** /data directory inside the container. Make sure /path/to/data are the same as other previous containers.
  • /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock is used to connect the host’s docker.socket to container’s docker.socket where you can run a container inside of another container

-d: run the container in detached mode
-v: mount code base and data files from host directory to container directory [host_div]:[container_dir]. By exposing the host directory to docker container, docker will be able to access data files within that mounted directory and use it to feed to the MIRA dashboard.
-p: map the host port to the container port and then all the requests that are made to the host port will be redirected to the Docker container [host_port]:[container_port]
--name: give a identity to the container

For more information about the Docker syntax, see Docker run reference

(5) To check if the container is built sucessfully 

docker container ps


CONTAINER ID   IMAGE                COMMAND                    CREATED        STATUS        PORTS                    NAMES
717b0825bc66   MIRA-prod:v1.0.0     "bash dashboard-kickoff"   5 hours ago    Up 5 hours    0.0.0.0:8050->8050/tcp   MIRA-prod

NOTE: Here we are publishing the MIRA-prod dashboard on port 8050 on the host machine. This port is different from the development version which was previously launched on port 8080.

(6) Access the MIRA dashboard on the host network

You can visit the local host using your preferred web browser, type in http://localhost:8050, and check if the dashboard is indeed hosted there.
